title: 112_hr3565
content: The Act titled "Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011" includes a provision for reducing the salaries of Members of Congress in response to the federal budget deficit. The Act "Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011" includes a provision for determining the salaries of Members of Congress based on the federal deficit. Salaries are adjusted based on the percentage of the deficit compared to the gross domestic product, with different percentages of the base rate applicable to the Member. The "Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011" links Members of Congress salaries to the federal deficit. The Secretary of the Treasury determines the deficit by comparing government outlays to receipts, and submits a report to Congress annually. The "Reconnecting Congress with America Act of 2011" ties Members of Congress salaries to the federal deficit. The base rates for different positions are specified, with the effective date set for pay periods after January 1, 2013. Members of Congress are encouraged to adjust their salaries voluntarily to reflect annual pay rate changes starting on January 1, 2013. Members of Congress are encouraged to adjust their salaries voluntarily to reflect annual pay rate changes starting on January 1, 2013. Retirement contributions for members of Congress are addressed in Section 3. Members of Congress' retirement contributions under the Civil Service Retirement System and Federal Employees' Retirement System will be adjusted by +/- 4.9 percentage points, respectively, starting from the enactment of this Act. Members of Congress' contributions to the Federal Employees' Retirement System will increase by 4.9 percentage points, while the government's contributions will decrease by the same amount, starting from the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. PROHIBITING TRADING BASED ON NONPUBLIC INFORMATION RELATING TO CONGRESS. The Commodity Exchange Act is amended to prohibit trading commodities based on nonpublic information related to Congress within 270 days of enactment. This includes information obtained by Members or employees of Congress, or from them, regarding pending legislative actions. The Commission will prohibit trading commodities based on nonpublic information derived from Federal employment within 270 days of enactment. This includes information obtained by federal employees or from them, relating to the commodity being traded. The term 'material nonpublic information' refers to information obtained by federal employees through their employment that has not been made available to the general public, including information exempt from disclosure, designated as confidential, or not disseminated to the public. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit buying or selling securities based on material nonpublic information related to pending legislative actions obtained from Congress members or employees. The Commission shall prohibit buying or selling securities based on material nonpublic information derived from Federal employment and relating to an issuer, if obtained by an employee of an agency or from such an employee. The term 'material nonpublic information' refers to information obtained by a federal employee that has not been made available to the general public, including information exempt from disclosure laws, designated as confidential, or not disseminated to the public. The House Committees on Agriculture and Financial Services will hold hearings on the implementation of certain sections of the Commodity Exchange Act and the Securities Exchange Act. This is an exercise of their rulemaking authority. The House of Representatives enacted rules as part of their rulemaking power, which supersede any other rule of the House if inconsistent. The House has the constitutional right to change these rules relating to House procedures at any time. Congress believes laws should apply to Members of Congress as they do to other individuals.
